sections.text:
**Scope:** 3 definition locks + 6 red-zone items only. Designed to be fast to complete and decision-ready for Meeting 4.

**How to use:** Deploy as a short form *or* as a structured script for 1:1 outreach (especially with high-salience dissenters).

**Guardrail for open text:** Only required when selecting “Cannot support …”; cap at **≤25 words** to prevent new scope creep and keep synthesis tractable.

---

heading_path: Section A — Definition locks (resolve ambiguity first)
sections.text:
Pick the definition FCCPS should use for high-stakes AI guidance (used for assessment restrictions, disclosure expectations, and due-process safeguards).

_Select one._

- **A** — High-stakes = work used for major summative decisions (final course grade components, graduation/placement decisions, standardized/end-of-course assessments, integrity investigations).
- **B** — High-stakes = any summative graded work above a threshold (e.g., ≥20% of term grade), plus standardized/end-of-course assessments.
- **C** — High-stakes = teacher-designated using a rubric (stakes + authenticity sensitivity + student age), documented in course guidance.
- **N** — Need more info / cannot decide from these options.

**Optional comment:** If you chose N, what’s the minimum clarification needed (≤25 words)?

---

heading_path: Section A — Definition locks (resolve ambiguity first)
D2 — Definition lock: What counts as “AI assistance” for disclosure/restrictions
sections.text:
Choose which categories of tools count as “AI assistance” for disclosure and restriction rules (this does NOT limit accessibility accommodations; it only defines what the rules apply to).

_Select one._

- **A** — Only GenAI content generation (drafting/rewriting/summarizing) and open-ended AI chat/tutoring tools.
- **B** — GenAI generation + AI-enabled editing (grammar/style/paraphrase) + AI chat/tutoring tools.
- **C** — All of the above PLUS AI features embedded in common platforms (predictive writing, smart compose) unless explicitly exempted.
- **N** — Need more info / cannot decide from these options.

**Optional comment:** If you chose N, name 1 tool category you think must be explicitly included or excluded (≤25 words).

---

heading_path: Section A — Definition locks (resolve ambiguity first)
sections.text:
Select the plain-language rubric FCCPS should adopt for risk-based AI limits (used to set “permitted / conditional / restricted” examples).

_Select one._

- **A** — 3-level rubric: Low-risk (practice/brainstorming), Medium-risk (graded formative), High-risk (high-stakes/summative). Apply grade-bands (K–5, 6–8, 9–12) for stricter defaults at younger ages.
- **B** — 2×2 matrix: Stakes (Low/High) × Autonomy (Independent/Supported). “High-stakes + Independent” gets the strongest limits and strongest process-evidence expectations.
- **N** — Need more info / cannot decide from these options.

**Optional comment:** If you chose N, what’s missing (≤25 words)?

---

heading_path: R1 — F3-04 — Common use-case language (decision-ready rewrite)
sections.text:
Choose the clause FCCPS should adopt for publishing clear, usable AI guidance (students + staff).

_Select one._

- **A** — FCCPS will maintain a living, grade-banded AI Use Guidance library for common student and staff tasks, showing permitted/conditional/restricted uses and required disclosure expectations; guidance will be updated when rules or tools change.
- **B** — FCCPS will publish grade-banded AI quick guides for common tasks (permitted/conditional/restricted) and update them on a regular cadence (e.g., annually), with school/class-level addenda as needed.
- **X** — Cannot support either option as written.

**Optional comment:** If you chose X, what is the single biggest defect to fix (≤25 words)?

---

heading_path: R2 — F3-05 — Assessment validity posture (decision-ready rewrite)
sections.text:
Choose the default posture for high-stakes assessment validity in an AI-available world.

_Select one._

- **A** — Hybrid default (recommended): FCCPS will protect high-stakes validity primarily through assessment design and process evidence (drafts/checkpoints/oral defense), applying AI restrictions only when validity cannot be preserved otherwise, using grade-banded rules.
- **B** — Restriction-first default: For high-stakes work, default to restricted AI conditions; allow AI only with explicit permission and controlled settings.
- **C** — Design-first default: For high-stakes work, default to robust design/process evidence rather than restrictions (restrictions rare).
- **X** — Cannot support any option as written.

**Optional comment:** If you chose X, name one guardrail or condition that would make an option acceptable (≤25 words).

---

Choose the FCCPS posture on AI detection tools for integrity decisions.

_Select one._

- **A** — Advisory-only with guardrails: Detector outputs may be used only after local validation for accuracy/bias; never sole evidence; must be corroborated by non-detector evidence and due process.
- **B** — No detectors in integrity decisions: Do not use detector tools in student integrity determinations (they may be used only for internal research/monitoring, not student-facing decisions).
- **X** — Cannot support either option as written.

**Optional comment:** If you chose X, what minimum constraint is required (≤25 words)?

---

heading_path: R4 — F3-15 — Notice / consent / opt-out (decision-ready rewrite)
sections.text:
Choose the FCCPS posture for notice/consent/opt-out regarding approved AI uses involving student data.

_Select one._

- **A** — Advance notice for all + consent/opt-out where feasible; default to data minimization and approved tools; require vendor terms that prohibit training models on FCCPS student data.
- **B** — Consent/opt-out required for any AI use involving student data (beyond legal minimums).
- **C** — Notice-only (opt-out only where legally required), with strong data minimization and approved-tool requirements.
- **X** — Cannot support any option as written.

**Optional comment:** If you chose X, what is the one must-have safeguard (≤25 words)?

---

Choose the clause FCCPS should adopt to avoid “mushy balance” and make the rule operational.

_Select one._

- **A** — Operational rule: When learning goals require independent practice, hands-on work, collaboration, or oral explanation, FCCPS will design tasks that require those modalities—even if AI is available—so AI supports (not replaces) intended skills.
- **B** — Principle-only rule: FCCPS will balance AI use with hands-on, collaborative, and offline learning experiences appropriate to age and purpose (educator judgment determines specifics).
- **X** — Cannot support either option as written.

**Optional comment:** If you chose X, what’s missing (≤25 words)?

---

Choose the FCCPS posture on AI assistance in teacher feedback to students.

_Select one._

- **A** — Guardrailed drafting (recommended): Educators may use AI to assist drafting feedback; educators must review, personalize, and own final feedback; AI cannot be the sole source of evaluative feedback or grades.
- **B** — Stronger constraint: Do not allow AI to generate evaluative feedback; AI may assist only with non-evaluative supports (e.g., rubric alignment, suggestion banks) under educator control.
- **X** — Cannot support either option as written.

**Optional comment:** If you chose X, state one acceptable boundary line (≤25 words).

---

heading_path: O1 — Optional: Identify your top “must-fix” items (to focus 1:1 follow-up)
sections.text:
Select up to TWO items that, if unresolved, would cause you to vote NO at Meeting 4.

_Select up to 2._

- **R2** — Assessment validity posture (R2)
- **R3** — Detector posture (R3)
- **R4** — Notice/consent/opt-out (R4)
- **R5** — Human-centered learning (R5)
- **R6** — Teacher-owned feedback (R6)
- **D1** — High-stakes definition (D1)
- **D2** — AI assistance scope definition (D2)
- **D3** — Risk-based rubric definition (D3)
